author: Josh Barbanel
title: A Queens Firehouse Goes From White Elephant to Cash Cow
text:
Back in 1981, Megan Dees Friedman happened upon a sturdy redbrick building with marble trim that had been the local firehouse in the age of horse-drawn engines. She had to have it.
The building was across the East River from her home on the Upper East Side, in a drab working-class section of Long Island City known as Dutch Kills. The listing broker described it as a “white elephant.” They settled on a price of $115,000.
